First, we have to find out the total book value which we denote with $TV$, where the debt issue $D$ is $\$95,000,000$ and the value issue $V$ is $\$40,000,000$

$$\begin{align*}
TV&=D+V\\[7pt]
&=95,000,000+40,000,000\\[7pt]
&=\$135,000,000
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the total book value is $\boxed{\$135,000,000}$

Second, we have to find out the actual market value of debt which we denote with $MD$, where the book value debit $BD$ is $\$95,000,000$ and the currently sells $CS$ is $93\%$

$$\begin{align*}
MD&=BD \times CS\\[7pt]
&=95,000,000 \times 93\%\\[7pt]
&=95,000,000 \times 0.93\\[7pt]
&=88,350,000
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the actual market value of debt is $\boxed{\$88,350,000}$

Third, we have to find out the actual market value of zero-coupon bond which we denote with $MZ$, where the book value issue $BI$ is $\$40,000,000$ and the bonds sells $BS$ is $67\%$

$$\begin{align*}
MZ&=BI \times BS\\[7pt]
&=40,000,000 \times 67\%\\[7pt]
&=40,000,000 \times 0.67\\[7pt]
&=26,800,000
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the actual market value of zero-coupon bond is $\boxed{\$26,800,000}$

Fourth,  we have to find out the total market value  which we denote with $T$, where the actual market value of debt $AD$ is $\$88,350,000$ and the actual market value of zero-coupon bond $AZ$ is $\$26,800,000$

$$\begin{align*}
T&=AD + AZ\\[7pt]
&=88,350,000+26,800,000\\[7pt]
&=\$115,150,000
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the total market value is $\boxed{\$115,150,000}$

Fifth, we have to find out the yield to maturity of zero-coupon bonds semi-annually by using an excel sheet which we denote with $YTM$, where the number of years $NPER$ $(8 \times 2)$ is $16$, $PMT$ is $0$, the pare value $PV$ $(1,000 \times 0.67)$ is $670$ and the face value $FV$ is $1,000$

$$\begin{align*}
YTM&=RATE(NPER,OMT,PV,FV)\\[7pt]
&=RATE(16,0,-670,1000)\\[7pt]
&=2.53\%
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the yield to maturity of a zero-coupon bond is $\boxed{2.53\%}$

Sixth, we have to find out the annual yield to maturity which we denote with $A$, where the yield to maturity zero-coupon bond $Y$ is $2.53\%$ and the semi-annually $S$ is $2$

$$\begin{align*}
A&=Y \times S\\[7pt]
&=2.53\% \times 2\\[7pt]
&=0.0253\times 2\\[7pt]
&=0.0506\\[7pt]
&=5.06\%
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the annual yield to maturity is $\boxed{5.06\%}$

Seventh, we have to find out the yield to maturity of pre tax cost of debt  by using an excel sheet which we denote with $YTM$, where the number of years $NPER$ $(30 + 27-3)$ is $54$, $PMT$ is $30$, the pare value $PV$ $(1,000 \times 0.93)$ is $930$ and the face value $FV$ is $1,000$

$$\begin{align*}
YTM&=RATE(NPER,OMT,PV,FV)\times 2\\[7pt]
&=RATE(54,30,-930,1000)\times 2\\[7pt]
&=6.56\%
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the yield to maturity of pre-tax cost of debt is $\boxed{6.56\%}$

Eighth, we have to find out the after tax cost of debt which we denote with $AD$, where the pre tax cost $PT$ is $6.56\%$ and the tax rate $T$ is $22\%$

$$\begin{align*}
AD&=PT \times (1-T)\\[7pt]
&=6.56\% \times (1-22\%)\\[7pt]
&=0.0656 \times (1-0.22)\\[7pt]
&=0.0656 \times 0.78\\[7pt]
&=0.051\\[7pt]
&=5.1\%
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the after-tax cost of debt is $\boxed{5.1\%}$

Ninth, we have to find out the after tax cost of debt of zero- coupon bond  which we denote with $AZ$, where the annual yield to maturity $AY$ is $5.06\%$ and the tax rate $T$ is $22\%$

$$\begin{align*}
AZ&=AY \times (1-T)\\[7pt]
&=5.06\% \times (1-22\%)\\[7pt]
&=0.0506 \times (1-0.22)\\[7pt]
&=0.0506 \times 0.78\\[7pt]
&=0.039\\[7pt]
&=3.9\%
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the after-tax cost of debt of zero- coupon bond is $\boxed{3.9\%}$

Tenth, let's find pot the best estimate of the cost of debt which we denote with $BE$, where the after-tax cost of debt $AD$ is $5.1\%$, actual market value of debt $MD$ is $\$88,350,000$, total market value $T$ is $\$115,150,000$, after-tax cost of debt of zero- coupon bond $AZ$ is $3.9\%$ and the actual market value of zero-coupon bond $MZ$ is $\$26,800,000$

$$\begin{align*}
BE &= AD \times \frac{MD}{T}+AZ \times \frac{MZ}{T}\\[12pt]
&=5.1\% \times \frac{88,350,000}{115,150,000}+3.9\% \times \frac{26,800,000}{115,150,000}\\[12pt]
&=0.051 \times \frac{88,350,000}{115,150,000}+ 0.039 \times \frac{26,800,000}{115,150,000}\\[12pt]
&=(0.051 \times 0.767)- (0.039 \times 0.232)\\[12pt]
&=0.0481\\[7pt]
&=4.81\%
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the best estimate of the cost of debt is $\boxed{4.81\%}$
